results.title: An Interview with Brigadier Keith Rossi
results.brief_description: Brigadier Keith Rossi went to join up but needed to lie about his age to do so. He tells of his time in the army with humour, capturing the cameraderie that helped alleviate the horror of war. In his time serving, he went from the Middle East, to New Guinea and, later, Vietnam, from Private to Brigadier.

results.title: An Interview with Jock McAuley
results.creator_credit: Jock McAuley and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Jock McAuley remembers hearing Prime Minister Menzies announcing Australia was at war. He was only 15 or 16 at the time and wondered if the would be still going by the time he was old enough to join. Against his dad’s wishes, Jock joined up and served as a pilot during the war. He tells of his experiences fighting for Australia.

results.title: An Interview with Stan Guilfoyle
results.brief_description: When he was 13, Stan Guilfoyle was in an accident in which he nearly died. From then on he believed in seizing every moment. This enthusiasm for life took him to the Royal Australian Air Force, where he became proficient at flying, using only the instruments in his cockpit to navigate. He tells of his time in Indonesia during World War II and passionately shares his views on war.

results.title: Defence of Milak = Memories of Milak
results.creator_credit: Keith Johnston and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Keith Johnston was a member of Btroop 2/10th commando squadron and served in Northern New Guinea during World War II. During the battle in Milak village, he was stuck in a pit with two others for over five days.
results.description: Keith Johnston was a member of Btroop 2/10th commando squadron and served in Northern New Guinea during World War II. During the battle in Milak village, he was stuck in a pit with two others for over five days.

results.title: An Interview with Alf Argent
results.brief_description: When Alf finished school, World War II had started. He signed up but was not called up for service until after he graduated from Duntroon at age 18. Alf then tells the story of his journey, through the Korean War, the Vietnam War to training in Europe and how he got to see the effects of war first-hand. A distinguished man who led an extraordinary life.

results.title: My life in the war years = My life during the war years
results.creator_credit: May Donovan and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: May Donovan was a young woman when World War II broke out. She speaks about her life in Melbourne and how she was affected by the war, despite being so far away. She is a member of the Victorian War Widows Guild and created this digital story in memory of Pat Medaris.

results.title: An Interview with Shirley Cornish
results.brief_description: Shirley Cornish joined the army when a friend, from the store where she worked, said she would. She joined the Australian Womens Army Service and spent most of her life in the service of the army, and tells of her times there and friends made. Army life often bled into Shirley’s personal life, losing a rank in order to spend more time with her mother and, later, joining the Bentleigh War Widows and Widowed Mothers after her husband died. Shirley considers joining this association to be the best thing she ever did and even went on to become its president.

results.title: An Interview with Billie Lindsay
results.brief_description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. She tells how she was immediately signed up while waiting for a friend, her time in Malaya and considers the way we look at war today and how her time in the army stood her in good stead later on in life.
results.description: Billie had just gone through training as a nurse when she was whisked away to war. results.title: Battle for Australia
results.creator_credit: Jean King and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: I have vivid memories of watching the Army march along Swanston Street, fit and tanned with heads held high, wearing the famous slouch hat. Jean King’s husband was a navy salvage diver during World War II, and she shares her experiences of being the wife of a war veteran as well as the toll the war took on families and the returned after the war

results.title: My naval experiences : World War II
results.creator_credit: Tom Clark and ACMI Digital Storytelling
results.brief_description: Tom Clark recalls the declaration of war against Germany by Prime Minister Menzies. He then shares his experiences of enlisting in the Navy in 1942 as a mid shipman, his time on the HMAS Kanimbla and fighting the Japanese in the Pacific
results.description: Tom Clark recalls the declaration of war against Germany by Prime Minister Menzies. He then shares his experiences of enlisting in the Navy in 1942 as a mid shipman, his time on the HMAS Kanimbla and fighting the Japanese in the Pacific
